div.p: S.G.: As the initials suggest, the 10 tetrameter couplets which serve as epigraph to the main text of Description seem to be SG’s own composition. SG returns later to the ‘misery’ of the scene of ‘death, / Where the Atheist yields his breath’.

the discovery: As SG explains, this discovery was normally attributed, in the early nineteenth century, to William Windham (1717-61) and Richard Pococke (1704-65), who made the first recorded expedition to the area in 1741; Windham’s record of the expedition, An Account of the Glacieres, or Ice Alps, in Savoy, was published in 1744. See Relation (p. 9), Voyages (2: p. 121), Troye (pp. 7-8), and introduction.

blazon…nature: In SWT, the Shelleys say of the French Revolution that it: ‘notwithstanding the temporary bloodshed and injustice with which it was polluted, has produced enduring benefits to mankind, which all the chicanery of statesmen, nor even the great conspiracy of kings, can render entirely vain’ (p. 107). In his Preface to The Revolt of Islam (London, 1818) – and indeed this was a primary purpose of the poem itself – Percy Shelley again seeks to explain ‘the excesses consequent upon the French Revolution’ and to emphasise the lasting benefits achieved: The French Revolution may be considered as one of those manifestations of a general state of feeling among civilized mankind produced by a defect of correspondence between the knowledge existing in society and the improvement or gradual abolition of political institutions (pp. vii, ix).

who look…God: Both the argument of this passage and the quotation are drawn from Alexander Pope (1688-1744), Essay On Man (1773-4), IV, 317-24:
See! the sole Bliss Heav’n could on all bestow,
Which who but feels, can taste, but thinks, can know:
Yet, poor with Fortune and with Learning blind,
The Bad must miss, the Good untaught will find,
Slave to no Sect, who takes no private road,
But looks thro’ Nature up to Nature’s GOD,
Pursues that Chain which links th’ immense Design,
Joyns Heav’n, and Earth, and mortal, and divine;
This direct address to the reader, in speech marks, is not (as far as I have been able to determine) taken from another source.

the renowned…Simplon: (46⁰ 15’ 6” N, 8⁰ 2’ 0 E”) A high Alpine pass linking Brig (in the Swiss Valais) with Domodossola (in Piedmont, Italy), and well-known amongst scholars of Romantic literature from Wordsworth’s account of crossing it in 1790, as told in Book IV of The Prelude (1805, 1850). In 1801, Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821) ordered the construction of a hard road across the pass in order to facilitate the movement of materiel over the Alps. The work was supervised by the engineer Nicolas Céard and completed in 1805. For a contemporary estimation, cp. Coxe:

It is quite impossible for language to convey any adequate idea of the wonders of the SIMPLON. To be described it must be seen. It combines throughout the awful and the sublime with the picturesque and the beautiful. There is not, perhaps, any place in the world where the astonished traveller will perceive, in such rapid succession, the wildest and rudest scenery intermingled with smiling vallies and cultivated fields. This wonderful monument of human labour and ingenuity, which may justly claim the admiration of the world extending from Geneva to Milan, was constructed by order of BONAPARTE, under the direction of M. CEARD, on whom it confers immortal honour (pp. 56-7). Troye offers on request ‘to amateurs in general’ a model of the Simplon Pass (p. i).

the celebrated… Bernard: Great St. Bernard Hospice (45º 52’ 08” N, 7º 10’ 14” E) is at 2649m on the Great St. Bernard Pass, which links Switzerland with Italy. It is described in detail in Voyages (2: pp. 368-80) and in most contemporary guide books, e.g. Coxe, pp. 176-82. Troye offers on request ‘to amateurs in general’ a model of ‘the PASSSAGE of the St. BERNARD’ (p. i).

valley of Bagnes: (46º 5’N, 7º 13’E) ‘The valley of Bagnes, in the Lower Valais, is ten leagues in length, and runs in the direction from W. to S. E. This valley, which is watered by the torrent of the Drance [Dranse de Bagnes], is very fertile, populous, and rich in picturesque scenery. The enormous glaciers of Tzermotane close this valley at the E. and S.; there being no road through it, it is not much frequented, but almost unknown’ (Ebel, p. 367). Ebel’s geography is inaccurate. Chermontane lies southwest not east of the Valley of Bagnes and at some distance from it Perhaps Ebel intends the Glacier de la Tsessette, on the east flank of the Grand Combin (4134m; 45º 56’ 15”N, 7º 17’ 57”E). Cp. Ebel: ‘This glacier [Tzermotan] directs its course southward towards the Combin, a mountain 13,252 feet above the sea’ (p. 368); and Pictet: ‘the waters of the Dranse, which are supplied by the glacier of Tzermotane and some others at the head of the valley’ (p. 88). Wall’s 1820 edition of Ebel makes no mention of the ‘frightful disasters’ of 1818. Troye offers on request ‘to amateurs in general’ a model of the ‘VALLEY of BAGNES, lately inundated’ (p. i).

Pays de Vaud: One of the cantons of Switzerland, bordering Lake Geneva; the capital is Lausanne. The territory, which had been under Bernese control since 1583, gained independence as the Lemanic Republic in 1798, was shortly thereafter made part of the Helvetic Republic, and finally denominated the Canton of Vaud by Napoleon’s Act of Mediation, which established the Swiss Confederation on 19 February 1803.

Saint Maurice: (46º 13’ N, 7º 0’ E) ‘SAINT MAURICE, is a small town in the Lower Valais, on the Rhone, between the Dent de Midi and the Dent de Morcles. Inns, La Maison de Ville, the town-house; La Croix Blanche, the white cross’ (Ebel, p. 369). Coxe notes in addition that it is ‘defended by a castle, and built almost entirely on a rock’, and that it has ‘a beautiful bridge of a single arch 200 feet in length, supposed to be the work of the Romans, in the middle of which is a small chapel’ (p. 61).

Piesvache: (41º 08’ 39” N, 7º 01’ 41” E) La Pissevache (Cascade de la Salanfe) is located at Vernayaz, between Saint Maurice and Martigny, in the Swiss Canton of Valais. Ebel comments: ‘This cascade descends eight hundred feet on a sloping rock, and is one of the highest waterfalls in Europe: it appears to most advantage at a distance, where the higher falls can be perceived: the best view of it is from the opposite side of the Rhône’ (p. 369). Coxe notes that the ‘perpendicular’ drop of ‘the most celebrated fall in the Valais’ is closer to 300 feet (p. 62). An illustration from 1794 is available here: https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pissevache#/media/File:Weibel_Pissevache-Wasserfall.jpg

Martigny: (46º 6’ N, 7º 4’ E). ‘MARTIGNY is a small town of the Lower Valais: it is divided into two separate parts, called the town and the castle. There are some Roman inscriptions; and the vineyards would be celebrated, if they were cultivated by a more industrious people. The principal inn is L’Aigle, or the eagle (at the castle, near the church), and La Grande Maison, the large house (in the town). Travellers, not to be plagued by the gnats, which are very troublesome in those parts, should endeavour to procure apartments at the top of the house’ (Ebel, pp. 360-1). See also Note 31.

the herculean…Buonaparte: The seemingly unmitigated admiration of Bonaparte’s ‘herculean works’ strikes a somewhat incongruous note in so ostensibly pious and conservative work as Description, but such praise is relatively common in contemporary guidebooks and indeed more generally (e.g. Coxe, pp. 56-7). Napoleon’s crossing of the Alps via the Great St. Bernard Pass in 1800, en route to victory over Austria the Battle of Marengo (14 June 1800), was often identified as his greatest military achievement and frequently compared to Hannibal’s crossing of the Alps ]in 218 BC (e.g. Coxe, pp. 173-5). See, as typical, the five canvasses (1801-5) by the French neoclassical painter Jacques-Louis David (1748-1825) depicting Napoleon Crossing the Alps. Cp., Byron writing of Jean-Jacques Rousseau’s novel Julie in his note to line 927 of the third canto of Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage (London, 1816):Rousseau has not been particularly fortunate in the preservation of the ‘local habitations’ he has given to ‘airy nothings’. The Prior of Great St. Bernard has cut down some of his woods for the sake of a few casks of wine, and Buonaparte has levelled part of the rocks of Meillerie in improving the road to Simplon. The road is an excellent one, but I cannot quite agree with a remark which I heard made, that ‘La route vaut mieux que les souvenirs’ (p. 78; ‘note 22, page 54, line 10’).

A phrase which is very much indebted to the influential formulation of the experience of the natural sublime by Edmund Burke (1729-97) in his Philosophical Enquiry into the Origins of Our Ideas of the Sublime and the Beautiful (1757).
the Dranse: SG means the Dranse de Bagnes; one of the tributaries of the Dranse, which joins the Rhône at Martigny.

The memorable…Italy: Hannibal of Carthage (247 - c.182 BC) led an army across the Alps in 218 BC during the Second Punic War, between Carthage and the Roman Republic. Although his exact route is still a matter of debate, in SG’s day, it was generally accepted that it involved what became the Little St. Bernard Pass. Hannibal’s achievement was frequently discussed in contemporary guidebooks and regularly compared to Napoleon’s crossing of the Great St. Bernard Pass in 1800 (e.g. Coxe, pp. 174-6).

whose dogs: The St. Bernard, or Alpine Mastiff, first bred at the Great and Little St. Bernard passes and used there as rescue dogs. Coxe comments: From November to May, a trusty servant, accompanied by an ecclesiastic, goes every day, half way down the mountain in search of travellers. They have with them one or two large dogs, trained for the purpose, which will scent a man at a great distance, and find out the road, in the thickest fogs, storms, and heaviest falls of snow. Suspended from their necks are little baskets with meat and drink to refresh the wearied traveller. These dogs are of a dusky fawn colour, mixed with white spots; they never offer to bite strangers, and seldom bark (p. 179).

vanished…vision: Cp. Shakespeare, The Tempest IV i 148-56:
These our Actors,
As I foretold you, were all Spirits, and
Are melted into Air, into thin Air,
And like the baseless Fabric of the Vision,
The Cloud-capp’d Tow’rs, the gorgeous Palaces,
The solemn Temples, the great Globe it self,
Yea, all which it inherit, shall dissolve,
And like this insubstantial Pageant faded
Leave not a rack behind.
Montpleureur: (46º 00’ 58.5” N, 07º 22’ 9.4” E) Le Pleureur (3704) is a mountain on the eastern side of the upper Valley of Bagnes, above what is today the Lac de Mauvoisin.

Mauvoisin: No peak today bears that name. Contemporary descriptions suggest that what was routinely referred to in SG’s day as Mont Mauvoisin (and sometimes as Malvoisin) was Becca de Corbassière (46º 0’ 51” N, 7º 18’ 32” E; 2749m) or Grand Tavé (45º 59’ 36” N, 7º 18’ 52” E; 3158m). Cf. Pictet: Mount Pleureur descends very rapidly into the valley of Bagne, and there forms with Mount Mauvoisin, which rises opposite to it, a pretty long gorge, in which the Dranse is confined in, a channel of from twenty to forty feet in breadth, and whose sides shoot up vertically to the height of about a hundred feet, so that the bridge of Mauvoisin, which connects the two sides of the valley, rests upon perpendicular rocks eighty feet above the bed of the river (p. 88).

The inhabitants: Arguments for the moral, civic and physical virtue of high Alpine communities are relatively common in the literature of the period and can be traced ultimately to Jean Jacques Rousseau’s fictionalised account of the inhabitants of the Valais in his celebrated novel Julie, ou la Nouvelle Héloïse: Lettres De Deux Amans, Habitans d’une Petite Ville au pied des Alpes (1761). Saussure offers an extended consideration the ‘morals of the inhabitants of Chamonix’ [‘Moeurs des Habitans de Chamouni’] in Voyages Dan Les Alpes (2: pp. 121-3), which emphasises their honesty, industry, and hospitality. In Relation, Marc Bourrit, noting that the inhabitants of Chamonix are ‘worthy, civic people’, asserts that ‘law-suits are unknown’ in the valley (pp. 58-9). In SWT, however, the Shelleys sound a dissenting note, recording, at Chamonix, ‘the degradation of the human species—who in these regions are half deformed or idiotic, and most of whom are deprived of any thing that can excite interest or admiration’ (pp. 162-3). The ‘proprietor’ of ‘the cabinet of Historie Naturelle’ at Chamonix they described as: ‘the very vilest specimen of that vile species of quack that, together with the whole army of aubergistes and guides, and indeed the entire mass of the population, subsist on the weakness and credulity of travellers as leaches subsist on the sick’ (pp. 170-1). See also Troye: The inhabitants of the Alps are seldom very tall or of a handsome stature, strength, rather than beauty, is their characteristic; neither do they live to a very advanced age; the fatigues of their younger days overpower them, and they generally die of inflammatory disorders. The labour, which elsewhere devolves on the men, falls there almost entirely on the women: they mow the grass, fell the wood, and thrash the corn. From this laborious life the women of Chamouni are so ill-favoured and so coarse in their features, that the comeliness of youth is rarely seen (p. 10).SG returns to the theme later.

do…by: The common English rendering of one of the precepts set out by Jesus in the Sermon on the Mount, according to Matthew 7:12: ‘Therefore all things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them: for this is the law and the prophets’.
Valley of Torembec: Now the Lac De Mauvoisin reservoir (49º 59’ 53” N, 7º 20’ 58” E), formed by the building of the Mauvoisin Dam across the Dranse de Bagnes in 1951-7.

FATAL…GETROZ: (45º 59’ 42” N, 7º 23’ 18” E) The Giétro Glacier, in the Upper Bagnes Valley. A contemporary illustration of the obstruction formed by the glacier is available here: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3b/Glacier_Gi%C3%A9tro_-_Escher_von_der_Linth%2C_1818.jpg

Although Wikipedia attributes this view to the Swiss Geologist Arnold Escher von der Linth (1807-72), who would have been 11 in 1818, it is rather more likely to have been taken by his father Hans Conrad (1767-1823), also a geologist, whose lecture on the disaster forms the basis of Pictet.
It is said…alarming degree: On the climatological conditions leading to the disaster, see Pictet, p. 88. For contemporary debates about glacial increase, see Note 67.
the Oratoire: Unidentified (not mentioned by Pictet).
able engineers: Hans Conrad Escher von der Linth (1767-1823) and Ignatz Venetz (1788-1859). See Note 22 and SG’s Note 2.
600 FEET: Both Inundation and Pictet give the length as 608 feet.
THE…FORTH: ‘fiat’ = divine command, from the Latin ‘let there be’.

Champsal: Champsec (46º 03’ N, 7º 15’ E), a village on the left bank of the Dranse de Bagnes and the closest major settlement to the source of the flood. Pictet does not mention it by name, but describes the effect on the upper valley of the ‘tremendous liquid mass’: which swept on every side the foot of the mountains, carrying thence forests, detached rocks, houses, barns, cultivated land, and laying waste even the base of those steep, but more or less cultivated, sides of the two chains of mountains bounding this unfortunate valley (p. 90).

Saint Bianchi: Sembrancher (46º 5’ N, 7º 9’ E), a village on the left bank of the Dranse de Bagnes, farther down the valley. Here, according to Pictet: ‘houses, highways, fields covered with the finest crops, noble trees loaded with fruit, every thing was swallowed up and devoured’ (p. 91).
Beauverniers: Bovernier (46º 5’ N, 7º 5’ E), another village on the left bank of the Dranse de Bagnes, still farther from the source of the flood. Pictet does not mention it.

Martigny: See Note 11. For the destruction at Martigny, see Pictet: the flood, which, reaching Martigny, and escaping from the narrow valley, diffuses itself over the plain, forming the great valley of the Rhone; covers the fields and orchards; runs through the town of Martigny; carries off from thence houses and barns; covers the whole plain with thick mud; thousands of trees torn up by the roots; wrecks of houses and furniture; dead bodies of men and animals; and, branching out, at last it precipitates itself into the bed of the Rhone (p. 91).
TWENTY FOUR…EIGHTY MINUTES: Pictet gives the distance travelled as 130,000 feet (c. 24.6 miles) and the time taken as ‘about’ ninety minutes (p. 91).
hope…them: Adapting Milton’s account of the condition of the fallen angels in Hell, in Paradise Lost I 66-7: ‘hope never comes / That comes to all’. The comparison is unfortunate.

the same disaster: Pictet sounds a similar note, remarking that the current condition of the Giétro Glacier ‘threatens, in the most alarming manner, the repetition in the course of next year of that scene of horror of which we have now been reading the details’: of what avail is the ‘fraternal aid’ offered by ‘all Switzerland’, he wonders, ‘if the same catastrophe is impending over them’ (pp. 93-4). Pictet suggests that only a substantial engineering work could make the valley safe against a repetition of the disaster and that such an effort would require the ‘whole nation’ to ‘unite around the altar of their native country’: Let us not overlook, in this dispensation, in this urgent and affecting case, in which man receives assistance from his neighbour, his fellow-citizen, and his country, the plan of Providence for uniting man with man, the village with its neighbour, the valley with a whole country, and every part of the nation with the whole nation. The free man respects those sacred bonds which give unity to every nation, and assures it civilization, duration, and happiness (p. 91).

Vale of TRIANT: The Valley of Trient (46º 3’ N, 7º 0’ E) lies southwest of Martigny, in the Swiss Canton of Valais. Coxe comments: After passing a long valley, which is terminated by an immense rampart of pines, it is not long before we distinguish several houses with a chapel: this is the village of Trient. Beyond this village is an opening between the mountains. Having gained at length this narrow straight, a landscape as delightful as it is unexpected, bursts upon the view (p. 54).

COL DE BALME: (46º 01’ 39” N, 06º 58’ 11” E) A mountain pass (2195 m) between Valais (Switzerland) and Haute Savoie (France), the Col de Balme does, as SG suggests, offer spectacular views over the Chamonix valley and Mont Blanc massif. By 1819, it had become a key site on the tourist itinerary at Chamonix. See Voyages (2: pp. 75-82) and Coxe: From its summit the Vallais, the Rhône, the large and small St. Bernard, the passages of Cenis and Simplon, St. Gothard, and the Alps of Berne and Unterwalden, are all discoverable: while the sublimity of this extensive view is greatly heightened by a near prospect of Mont Blanc and its majestic needles (p. 45). A painting of the view by the Swiss artist Jean-Antoine Linck (1766-1843) is available here: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/CH-NB_-_Balme%2C_Col_de%2C_und_Tal_von_Chamonix_mit_Mont_Blanc%2C_von_Nordosten_-_Collection_Gugelmann_-_GS-GUGE-LINCK-B-11.tif/lossy-page1-5906px-CH-NB_-_Balme%2C_Col_de%2C_und_Tal_von_Chamonix_mit_Mont_Blanc%2C_von_Nordosten_-_Collection_Gugelmann_-_GS-GUGE-LINCK-B-11.tif.jpg?uselang=en-gb

Aurora…dews: ‘Rosy-fingered’ (rhododáktylos) is a frequent Homeric epithet for Eos / Aurora, goddess of the dawn. Many eighteenth- and early-nineteenth century dictionaries and encyclopaedia, including Encyclopaedia Britannica, use the identical phrase of Aurora that ‘The Poets [i.e. Classical writers] represent her as rising out of the ocean in a chariot, with rosy fingers dropping gentle dew’, though in Classical sources the dew was most often tears.

MONT BLANC: (45º 50’ 01” N, 6º 51’ 54” E) The highest mountain in western Europe (4808m). The summit was first reached on 8 August 1786, by Jacques Balmat (1762-1834), who had earlier discovered a practicable route, and Michael Gabriel Paccard (1757-1827). After two failed attempts (in 1774 and 1785), the Swiss natural philosopher Horace-Bénédict de Saussure (1740-99) reached the summit on 3 August 1787, and subsequently published accounts of the climb in Abregée and Voyages (4: pp. 137-216). A depiction of Saussure’s ascent by the Swiss engraver Christian Von Mechel (1737-1817) is available here: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Descent_from_Mont-Blanc_in_1787.jpg?uselang=en-gb
The extended description of an ascent of Mont Blanc with which SG concludes Description is essentially a translation from Voyages. See introduction.

monarch of the vale: The conceit was relatively common in the literature of the period, e.g. Byron, Manfred, a Dramatic Poem (1816), I i 60-3; Percy Shelley, ‘Mont Blanc’ (1816), ll. 60-3; And Coxe: The Mer de Glace is eight leagues in length, and one in breadth; and on its margin rise pyramidical rocks, called needles, whose summits are lost in the clouds; they are also denominated the Court of their august Sovereign Mont-Blanc, who glitters, on the opposite side in stately repose, and being far more elevated than her attendants, veils in the heavens, which she seems to prop, a part of her sublime and majestic beauties (pp. 40-1).

LE GEANT: (45º 51’ 43” N, 6º 57’ 6” E) Dent du Géant (4013m) is a peak in the Mont Blanc massif. Not to be confused with the Col du Géant (45º 50’ 56” N, 6º 56’ 05” E; 3356m), a high Alpine pass in the Mont Blanc massif, a detailed survey of which was the object of Saussure’s fifth Alpine ‘voyage’ See Voyages (4: pp. 217-321).
corruscations: luminous, atmospheric effects; cp. Erasmus Darwin, Botanic Garden I n.3 on ‘the coruscations of the Aurora Borealis’.

Hail…whole: Much quoted in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries in almanacs, primers, and the likes, and especially those with an evangelical leaning, the lines SG quotes here first appeared as part of a poetical essay entitled ‘Of Astronomy’, above the pseudonym ‘Urbanicus’, in the Gentleman’s Magazine for September 1733 (No 4, p. 503). In SG’s day, they were usually attributed, somewhat imprecisely, to ‘William Browne’, ‘Reverend Brown’, or simply ‘Brown’, possibly based on a confusion of Moses Brown (1738-1836) and William Browne (c.1590-c.1645).

ARVE: The river Arve flows through the Chamonix valley from its sources in various mountain torrents near the Col De Balme, eventually joining the Rhône at Geneva. Windham (p. 29), Relation (p. 140), and Ebel (p. 409), each note that the river contains gold. Cp. Percy Shelley, ‘Mont Blanc’ ll. 12-48 on the ‘Ravine of Arve – dark, deep Ravine’.

TORRENT…cavern: A major tributary of the Arve, which it joins near the centre of Chamonix, L’Arveyron has its source in the Mer de Glace Glacier (see Note 51). In SG’s day, the river emerged from a spectacular cavern of ice at the foot of the glacier making the site one of the premier tourist attractions in the valley. For contemporary descriptions see Windham (p. 29), Voyages (2: pp. 14-19), Troye (pp. 10-11), and Coxe (pp. 38-41), which identifies the Mer de Glace and the source of the Arveyron as ‘two objects infinitely better worth seeing than any others which present themselves in this excursion [around Chamonix]’ (p. 38). For the Shelleys’ impression, see SWT pp. 156-7. A painting of the scene by the German artist Carl Hackert (1740-96) is available here: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/49/Carl_Hackert_Vue_de_la_Source_de_l_Arveron.jpg
See also Note 62.

L’ARGENTIERES: (45º 57’ 34” N, 7º 01’ 13” E) Aiguille d’Argentière (3901m): one of the summits of the Mont Blanc massif mentioned in passing by most contemporary accounts of Chamonix. Troye gives the height as 11412 feet.
craggy rocks…TOURS: (45º 59’ 39” N, 7º 0’ 35” E) Aiguille du Tour (3540m): one of the summits of the Mont Blanc massif mentioned in passing by most contemporary accounts of Chamonix.

the Druid’s point: (45º 55’ 58” N, 6º 57’ 23” E) Aiguille du Dru (3745m): one of the summits of the Mont Blanc massif mentioned in passing by most contemporary accounts of Chamonix and described in detail in Voyages (2: pp. 6-8). Cp. also Relation, which describes it as ‘a most magnificent pyramid’ (p. 78). See also Note 79.

BREVEN: (45º 56’ 03” N, 06º 50’ 16” E) Le Brévent (2525) is a peak in the Aiguilles Rouges, on the northern side of the Chamonix valley, which commands a truly spectacular, panoramic view of the Mont Blanc massif. The ascent and the view are described in Relation (pp. 63-74), Voyages (2: pp. 33-49) and Coxe (pp. 206-10), which reproduces Bourrit’s account. See also Notes 71, 74.
Pococke…Windham: See Notes 2, 51, 54, 56, 67, and 94, and introduction.
rude: ‘rustic’, ‘unpolished’ (not ‘impolite’).

THE SEA OF ICE: (45º 54’ 58” N, 6º 56’ 14” E) The Mer de Glace: the largest glacier in France. First described in Windham (pp. 9-13), which notes that ‘The Description which Travellers give of the Seas of Greenland seems to come the nearest to it. You must imagine your lake [meaning Lake Geneva] put in Agitation by a strong Wind, and frozen all at once; perhaps even that would not produce the same Appearance’ (pp. 9-10) – thereby giving rise to the name mer de glace. By SG’s day, it was (as indeed it remains today) one of the premier attractions of the Chamonix valley. Coxe describes it as ‘infinitely better worth seeing’ than anything else in the valley of Chamonix (p. 38). For the Shelleys’ response to ‘the Sea of Ice, a scene in truth of dizzying wonder’, see SWT pp. 156-7, 164-7 (164). Contemporary paintings by the Swiss artist Carl Ludwig Hackert (1740-96) and the German artist Carl Gustav Carus (1789-1869) are available here: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CH-NB_-_Mer_de_Glace_depuis_le_Montenvers_-_Collection_Gugelmann_-_GS-GUGE-HACKERT-B-7.tif?uselang=en-gb and here: http://www.the-athenaeum.org/art/full.php?ID=221441
See also Notes 43, 67, 91 and 94.
THE EVER-VERDANT…SNOW: See Note 103. Windham does not mention this location, which is first described in Voyages (2: p. 28).
THE GLACIERS: See Notes 81, 82, 83, 84, 85 and 86.

the Prieure: For much of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, the main settlement in the valley of Chamonix was known as ‘Prieure’, or ‘the Priory’, after the Benedictine priory which was established there in the thirteen century (see, for example, Relation pp. 56-7, Ebel p. 106). The building is clearly visible in this view of the valley by the Swiss artist Jean-Antoine Linck (1766-1843): https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/75/Le_prieur%C3%A9_de_Chamouni%2C_le_mont_Blanc%2C_l%27aiguille_du_Go%C3%BBter%2C_le_glacier_des_Bossons_-_Gravure_de_Jean-Antoine_Link_%28fin_XVIII%C3%A8%29.jpg
Arrived at Chamonix in June 1741, Windham and Pococke found ‘The Prior of this Place was a good old Man’ who ‘endeavoured to dissuade’ them from ascending the glaciers (Windham, p. 5).

two excellent Inns: Ebel observes that ‘Three large inns, as good as those of any town, can hardly suffice for the number of travellers, who, from all parts of Europe, visit the priory of Chamouny’ and identifies the ‘principal inns [as] those of Madame Couterant and M. Terraz’ (pp. 376, 377). These were the Hôtel de Londres, where the Shelleys would stay in July 1816, and the Hôtel d’Angleterre, which housed Byron later that same summer – and whose names confirm that the majority of visitors to Chamonix were British. Percy Shelley made ‘atheist’ inscriptions in the registers of both hotels. See: https://www.trin.cam.ac.uk/news/shelleys-shocking-atheist-declaration-rediscovered-after-200-years/

unnecessary precautions: Windham and Pococke were heavily armed on their expedition to Chamonix in 1741, slept in tents rather than local accommodation, and kept fires burning throughout the night – and Windham’s Account recommends similar caution to subsequent travellers. SG translates more-or-less verbatim from Voyages (2: p. 122): ‘Les vieillards de Chamouni s’en ressouviennent; & ils rient encore des craintes de ces voyageurs & de leurs precautions inutiles’.

Altho’…guides: This entire paragraph is translated verbatim from Voyages (2: p. 122). Percy Shelley describes his guide, Ducrée, as ‘the only tolerable person I have seen in this country’ (SWT, p. 157; but cp. 170-1). Cp. also Troye (p. 9), which praises ‘the qualities and use of the guides’.

principal commerce: Cp. Troye: A considerable commerce in cheese is carried on in the Valley of Chamouni. Honey is also one of the objects of exportation; it is excellent in quality, and remarkable for its whiteness, which is attributed to the larch trees abounding here, from which the bees chiefly collect their store (p. 10).Saussure praises the honey of Chamonix, identifies larch trees as the most likely explanation of its special flavour and colour, and comments on the quality of the pasturage (Voyages 2: pp. 134-6). The remark about the ‘furious AVALANCHES’ is SG’s own.
Chrystals: SG’s two paragraphs on crystals and crystal hunters are translated verbatim from Voyages (2: pp. 123-4).

The…mountain-goat: A mountain goat, native to Europe. SG’s three paragraphs on them are based, more-or-less verbatim, on Voyages (2: pp. 124-7). One of the most celebrated episodes of Byron’s Manfred, A Dramatic Poem (1817) concerns a chamois-hunter who saves the life of the titular character (I ii); the scene is the subject of John Martin’s (1789-1854) painting Manfred on the Jungfrau (1837).

The infatuation…atoms: The ‘traveller’ in question is Saussure. Cp. Voyages (2: pp. 126-7): D’Aprés ce tableau fidelle de la vie des chasseurs de chamois, peut-on comprendre que cette chasse soit l’object d’une passion absolument insurmontable? J’ai connu un jeune homme de la paroisse de Sixt, bien fait, d’une jolie figure, qui venoit d’épouser une femme charmante: il me disoit à moi-même, ‘mon grand pere est mort à la chasse, mon pere y est mort; je suis si persuade que j’y mourrai, que ce sac que vous me voyez, Monsieur, & que je porte à la chasse, je l’appelle mon drap mortuaire; parce que je suis sûr que je n’en aurai jamais d’autre; & pourtant si vous m’offriez de fair ma fortune, à condition de renouncer à la chasse au chamois, je n’y renoncerois pas’. J’ai fait sur les Alpes quelques courses avec cet home; il étoit d’une addresse & d’une force étonnante; mais sa témérité étoit plus grand encore que sa force; & j’ai fu que deux ans après, le pied lui avoit manqué au bord d’un précipice, où il avoit subi la desintée à laquelle il s’étoit si bien attend. [After this faithful depiction of the life of the chamois hunters, is it possible to understand that this hunt can be the object of an absolutely insurmountable passion? I knew a young man from the parish of Sixt, strong, handsome, who had just married a charming young woman: he said to me, ‘my grandfather died hunting, my father too; I am persuaded that I will also, that this sack which you see me with, Sir, and which I carry during the hunt, will be my funeral shroud; and yet if you offered to make my fortune on condition of my renouncing the hunt, I would not renounce it’. I made a number of journeys in the Alps with this man; he had an impressive bearing and strength; but his bravery was even greater than his strength; I learned two years later, that he had lost his footing at the edge of a precipice, and suffered that fate which he had expected (my translation)]

Cavern…Tours: This reference offers something of a puzzle and SG seems to conflate several different sites and incidents. Contemporary guidebooks make no mention of a cavern ‘extending half a league’ (almost 2.5 km) under the Glacier du Tours and SG’s description seems to conflate both glacial and speleological features. In fact, the ‘celebrated’ location to which SG refers is almost certainly the Grotte de Balme (46º 02’ 32”N, 6º 37’ 02” E) near Magland, first described at length by Bourrit in Relation (pp. 25-31), and then by Saussure in Voyages (1: pp. 320-5), and thereafter by most of the major guidebooks, including Coxe, which quotes Bourrit’s account in full (pp. 44-8), and Ebel, which notes that ‘the access to it is rather difficult, but may be accomplished with the assistance of guides’ (p. 382). Relation provides considerable detail about the mineral formations in the cavern, but does not mention any marine fossils; Voyages, however, discusses them at length (1: pp. 321-2), which suggests that it was SG’s source. However, I have found no mention of the ‘melancholy circumstance’ which SG describes as occurring at the Grotte de Balme. Bourrit, indeed, reports that his party ‘ventured to throw’ a ‘lighted grenade’ in order to appreciate the echoes caused (Relation, p. 29). But cp. Raffles on an accident at the source of the Arveyron (see Note 44) on 8 August 1797: a Mons. Maritz, of Geneva […] with his son and nephew, walked some little distance under the arch — for the river does not occupy the whole space beneath — and there, for mere amusement, he fired his pistol. But he paid dearly for his rashness; for, not instantly retreating, an enormous mass of ice fell upon them all, and buried them beneath its weight. He himself escaped with a broken leg, his nephew was dreadfully mangled, but his son was killed (p. 172).This accident was sufficiently well-known to still be described by Murray (p. 297). Hence SG is almost certainly conflating, in this passage of Description, accounts of the Grotte de Balme and of the source of the Arveyron, which he describes separately. Today the Grotte de Balme (which is not to be confused with the now better-known Grottes de la Balme) is only accessible with a guide. See http://www.savoie-mont-blanc.com/offre/fiche/grottes-de-balme/81523

abounding…productions: The discovery of marine fossils (often of creatures no longer apparently extant) at high altitudes played an important role in the various late eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century debates in natural philosophy from which the science of geology would emerge. Notable amongst these was the debate between the so-called ‘Plutonists’ and ‘Neptunists’ about the dynamics of geomorphic change, that is, between those who argued that volcanic activity was the primary agent of such change and those who argued that water (whether in the form of a Biblical Deluge or otherwise) was responsible. That so ostensibly pietist a text as Description offers no comment on these fossils is interesting, though SG’s emphasis on their abundance might be taken as comment of a sort. For more detailed discussion of the contours of these debates ‘around the time that Saussure climbed Mont Blanc’, see Martin Rudwick, Bursting the Limits of Time: The Reconstruction of Geohistory in the Age of Revolution (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2007), pp. 239-87 (260).

stalactites or spars: Stalactites are mineral structures suspended from the roof of a cave or cavern (as opposed to stalagmites, which rise from the floor); in SG’s day, the term ‘spar’, in natural philosophy, referred to various crystalline formations.

Damocles: According to legend, a courtier in Syracuse in the fourth century BC who was made, by the king, to sit under a sword held in place by a single hair from a horse’s tail, in order to appreciate the anxiety and danger of rule.
ponderous: ‘Having great weight’, ‘massive’ (OED 1).

increase and decrease: The behaviour of the glaciers at Chamonix had been a subject of debate since Windham and Pococke’s seminal encounter with them in 1741. Windham records of the Mer de Glace (see Note 51): Our Guides assured us, that, in the time of their Fathers, the Glaciere was but small, and that there was a Passage thro’ these Valleys, by which they could go into the Val d’Aoste [on the Italian side of the Mont Blanc massif] in six Hours: But that the Glaciere was so much increased, that the Passage was then quite stopped up, and that it went on increasing every year (p. 13). Saussure, noting the general opinion of the locals that the glaciers were then increasing and would continue to do so, confirms that belief to be more accurate in terms of length than of height and thickness, and that, on the whole, the available evidence supported the idea of periods of increase and decrease (Voyages 1: pp. 385-6). In SWT, the Shelleys, noting the conflict between the opinion of Saussure and the locals on this point, deem the latter ‘more probable’ and conclude that the glaciers of the Mont Blanc massif ‘must augment and will subsist, at least until they have overflowed this vale [of Chamonix]’ (pp. 161-2). In ‘Mont Blanc’, however, Shelley emphasises the beneficial rather than the calamitous effects of glaciation, which ultimately provides, via mineral-rich rivers, ‘the breath and blood of distant lands’ (l. 124).
spiring needles: As many contemporary sources observe, a number of the rocky summits above Chamonix were (and still are) known as ‘aiguilles’, the French word for ‘needles’.

Oft rushing…whelm’d: Quoting James Thomson, The Seasons, ‘Winter’, ll. 416-22. In Thomson’s text, line 420 reads ‘And herds, and flocks, and travellers, and swains’; and line 421 reads ‘Are deep within the smothering ruin whelm’d!!’.
coup-d-essai: ‘First attempt’, ‘Trial’.

7086 feet: SG is mistaken here. The actual height of Le Brévent is 2525m (c. 8284ft). Murray gives it as ‘about 8300 English feet’, presumably following Relation (‘Heights above the Mediterranean Sea’, np) and Voyages (2; frontispiece map), both of which give approximately the same figure. Troye gives 7836 ‘English feet’ (‘Numerical Reference the Model’, np), which is closer to SG’s figure. Troye gives the elevation of the Col de Balme as 7086 feet, so perhaps SG confused the two. Cp. also Ebel (p. 374): ‘The highest part of the Col de Balme, where stands an iron cross, is 7,086 feet above the sea, according to M. de Saussure’. This seems to be itself an error: Voyages gives the heights of Col de Balme and Croix de Fer as 1181 and 1306 toises respectively (i.e. as c. 7551 feet and c. 8351 feet).
twenty years: See introduction.

Soon…orient pearls: Cp. Milton, Paradise Lost V 1-2: ‘Now Morn her rosy steps in the eastern clime / Advancing, sowed the earth with orient pearl’. Thomson describes ‘The meek-ey’d Morn, mother of dews’ in The Seasons, ‘Summer’, ll. 46-7.

la Cheminee: The final section of the ascent of Le Brévent from Planpraz, via the Col du Brévent and Brèche du Brévent. It has been protected by ladders since the late nineteenth century and was not infrequently made the subject of postcards in the early twentieth century. See, for example: http://www.collection-cartespostales.com/7393-thickbox_default/74-chamonix-mont-blanc-cheminee-du-brevent.jpg Murray comments: At the end of an hour from Planpra [sic.], the path reaches the base of a steep rock, which it is necessary to climb, by a sort of open chimney about 50 feet high. To clamber up this perpendicular gulley is one of the feats of which travellers boast; those, however, who do not value the glory it confers, or will not set it against the risk, go on half a mile, and find a convenient path by which this precipitous rock can be surmounted (p. 413).
Jura: A sub-Alpine mountain range along the French-Swiss border, northwest of Geneva. Described in Voyages (1: pp. 223-40) and in many contemporary guide books.

Geneva: (46º 12’ N, 6º 09’ E) City on the southwest shore of Lake Geneva (known in SG’s day as Lac Léman); annexed by Directorate France in 1798, Geneva was incorporated into the Swiss Confederation on 1 June 1814, after the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte. Troye offers on request ‘to amateurs in general’ a model of the ‘CITY OF GENEVA, carved in Wood’ (p. i).
600 feet: See Voyages (2: p. 6), and Murray (p. xlix) for the wide dissemination of this figure.
Tacul: (45º 51’ 23” N, 06º 53’ 16” E) Mont Blanc du Tacul (4248m): one of the summits of the Mont Blanc massif mentioned in passing by most contemporary accounts of Chamonix.

the Druid’s mysteries: Neither Relation nor Voyages comments on the origins of the name of the Aiguille du Dru and the (faulty) etymological speculation about ‘druids’ may by SG’s own. On the general association of the Mont Blanc massif with occult mysteries, cp. Windham (pp. 12-13), Relation (pp. 8-9) and Voyages (2: p. 121): Le petit peuple de notre ville [Chamonix] & des environs donne au Mont Blanc & aux montagnes couvertes de neige qui l’entourent, le nom de montagnes maudites; & j’ai moi-même ouï dire dans mon enfance à des paysans, que ces neiges éternelles étoient l’effet d’une malediction que les habitans de ces montagnes s’étoient attire par leurs crimes. [The small population of our town [Chamonix] and the surrounding area give the Mont Blanc and the snow-covered mountains which surround it the name of the accursed mountains; and I myself have heard in my infancy from these peasants that these eternal snows were the effect of a curse which the inhabitants of these mountains had attracted by their crimes (my translation)]The tradition is reflected to this day in naming of Mont Maudit (45º 50’ 52” N, 6º 52’ 33” E; 4465m), the second highest peak in the French part of the Mont Blanc massif, adjacent to Mont Blanc itself.

melancholy proof: I have found no source for SG’s anecdote, though that is no reason to doubt its veracity. Saussure felt of the Aiguille du Dru that it was ‘absolument inaccessible dans toute sa hauteur’ [‘incapable of being summited’ (my translation)] (Voyages 2: p. 7); the first successful (recorded) ascent was made on 12 September 1878.
les Pelerins: (45º 53’ 32” N, 6º 53’ 17” E) Glacier de Pélerins. Described in detail in Relation (pp. 84-92).

du Bossons: (45º 52’ 40” N, 6º 52’ 00” E) Glacier des Bossons. Described in detail in Relation (pp. 140-7) and Voyages (2: pp. 50-2), where Saussure remarks that it is one of the ‘curiosités de la vallée de Chamouni que voient la plupart des étrangers’ [‘one of the curiosities of the valley of Chamouni most visited by foreigners’ (my translation)]. For the Shelleys’ impressions, see SWT, pp. 154-5, 157-9. A view of the glacier by the Swiss painter Jean-Antoine Linck (1766-1843) is available here: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CH-NB_-_Mont_Blanc_und_Glacier_des_Bossons_-_Collection_Gugelmann_-_GS-GUGE-LINCK-A-3.tif?uselang=en-gb

Tacona: (45º 50’ 00” N, 6º 50’ 45” E) Glacier de Tacconaz. Described in Voyages, where Saussure notes that it seems ‘considérablement augmenté’ [‘considerably increased’ (my translation)] since he first saw it in 1760 (Voyages 1: p. 361; see also 4: pp. 150-3, for a detailed description). See also Note 67.

l’Agria: (45° 51’ 43” N, 06° 49’ 19” E) Glacier de la Griaz. Mentioned in Ebel as one of the ‘less considerable’ glaciers to depend from Mont Blanc (p. 376) and principally known for the torrent which flowed from it (see Voyages 1: p. 361).

des Ouches: SG presumably means various glaciers above the hamlet of Les Houches (45º 53’ 27” N, 6º 47’ 57” E), including Griaz, Tacconaz and Bionnassay; for Les Houches and its glaciers, see Voyages (1: p. 361).
Bionassy: (45º 50’ 00” N, 6º 48’ 30” E) Glacier de Bionnassay. Mentioned only in passing by Saussure (Voyages 2: pp. 141-2, 145-6) and other contemporary accounts.

almost inaccessible: SG’s oxymoron reflects the fact that the trope of inaccessibility had for some time been the preferred means of describing the highest peaks at Chamonix, including Mont Blanc itself, even after the summit had been reached, as in Percy Bysshe Shelley’s ‘Mont Blanc’, which describes the mountain as ‘Remote, serene, and inaccessible’ (l. 96). The trope is still in use today: ski-lift and cable-car passes issued by the Compagnie du Mont Blanc bear the strapline L’Exceptionnel Accessible [‘the exceptional accessible’ (my translation)]. For a more detail discussion of the trope, see Cian Duffy, The Landscapes of the Sublime, 1700-1830: Classic ground (London: Palgrave, 2013), pp. 46-50.
hide…heads: Taken from Satan’s address to the sun in Milton, Paradise Lost iv 34-5: ‘at whose sight all the stars / Hide their diminished heads’.
At first…blaze: Quoting James Thomson, The Seasons, ‘Summer’, ll. 1133-40.
Sudden…waste: Quoting James Thomson, The Seasons, ‘Winter’, ll. 993-7; in Thomson’s text, line 995 reads: ‘A thousand snow-fed torrents shoot at once’.

Montalvert: (45º 55’ 59” N, 6º 55’ 02” E) Montenvers (1913m), the part of the Mont Blanc massif on the eastern edge of the Mer de Glace glacier, which Windham and Pockocke ascended to view that glacier, and which subsequently became (and still remains) the main viewpoint for tourists. Described in detail in Voyages (2: pp. 1-13) and most other accounts and guidebooks. Percy Bysshe Shelley made an atheist inscription in the guest book at ‘the cabin of Montanvert’; for the Shelleys’ impression of the scene, see SWT, pp. 164-8 (164). A view of tourists at Montenvers by the Swiss painter Carl Ludwig Hackert (1740-96) is available here: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CH-NB_-_Mer_de_Glace_depuis_le_Montenvers_-_Collection_Gugelmann_-_GS-GUGE-HACKERT-B-7.tif?uselang=en-gb
Various spellings were current in SG’s day, but that given here could actually be a compositor’s error. Cp. Note 131; see also Note 51.
NATURE’S GOD: An expression potentially susceptible to sceptical interpretation.

once…waves: Numerous accounts from Windham onwards note that the Mer de Glace has the appearance of a sea or lake frozen during a storm. For SG’s formulation here and his ‘opinion as to the cause’ (expressed below), cp. Coxe on the Mer de Glace: we cannot, perhaps, give a better idea than by comparing it to a tempestuous ocean whose towering waves have suddenly been rendered motionless by an All-powerful Hand, and converted into solid masses of crystal (p. 40). And Raffles: if you then imagine innumerable torrents to roll impetuously from the summits of the mountains — conceive them as collected by those two glens, poured into this deep ravine, and as they hurry, to dash with their accumulated waters down the precipice into the lower valley, arrested by a mighty hurricane — wrought into the wildest forms by the fury of the tempest — and then, by the fiat of the Almighty, instantly congealed — if, moreover, you add the innumerable fissures and chasms torn in the ice by the undermining torrents and the unevenness of the bed below, — you will have a tolerably correct idea of the sea of ice (p. 164).

presumption…cause: Speculation was, of course, part and parcel of early nineteenth-century natural philosophy. For this questioning idiom, cp. Percy Shelley’s ‘Mont Blanc’, which contains no fewer than six extended queries about the origins and significance of the landscape. Cp. however SG’s condemnation throughout Description of atheists and of atheistic responses to Alpine landscape as ‘presumptuous’.
this…elements: Quoting Jospeh Addison, Cato, a Tragedy (1731), V i 28, a passage on which SG draws again later.

Of him…END: Adapting ll. 1-2 and 7-8 of the Anglican hymn ‘O Thou whose power o’er moving worlds presides’, translated by Samuel Johnson from the Latin of Boethius:
O Thou, whose power o’er moving worlds presides,
Whose voice created, and whose wisdom guides,
On darkling man in pure effulgence shine,
And cheer the clouded mind with light divine!
’Tis thine alone to calm the pious breast
With silent confidence, and holy rest;
From thee, great God! we spring – to thee we bend,
Path, Motive, Guide, Original, and End! Quoted here from William Bengo Collyer’s (1782-1854) compilation, Hymns, Partly Collected and Partly Original (London: Longman, 1812), p. 610.

the icy God: SG presumably means Winter. But cp. SWT: Do you, who assert the supremacy of Ahriman, imagine him throned among these desolating snows, among these palaces of death and frost, so sculptured in this their terrible magnificence by the adamantine hand of necessity, and that he casts around him, as the first essays of his final usurpation, avalanches, torrents, rocks, and thunders, and above all these deadly glaciers, at once the proof and symbols of his reign (p. 162).The passage is based on a letter from Percy Bysshe Shelley to his friend Thomas Love Peacock (1785-1866) of 23 July 1816. Peacock was then working on a poem (which he never finished) called Ahrimanes, which had as its subject the conflict between good (Oromaze) and evil (Ahrimanes) as described by the Zoroastrian faith. See also Notes 105, 107, and introduction.
sylvan: ‘woodland’.
cloven-footed fauns: ‘deities of the country, represented as having the legs, feet, and ears of goats, and the rest of the body human. They were called satyrs by the Greeks’ (Lemprière).

the pastoral pipe: The syrinx, played by Pan, patron deity of the countryside. ‘He invented the flute with seven reeds, which he called Syrinx, in honour of a beautiful nymph of the same name, to whom he attempted to offer violence, and who was changed into a reed’ (Lemprière).

dryades…nymphs: ‘female deities among the ancients. They were generally divided into two classes, nymphs of the land and nymphs of the sea. Of the nymphs of the earth, some presided over woods, and were called Dryades and Hamadryades; others presided over mountains and were called Oreades; some presided over hills and dales, and were railed Napaeae, etc.’ (Lemprière).

The Garden: SG’s geography is a little out. Contemporary sources locate the spot known as Le Jardin (or Le Courtil, in the local dialect) not on the Mer de Glace proper but above it on the Glacier de Talèfre (45º 54’ 56” N, 6º 59’ 39”), which joins with the Glacier de Leschaux to form the Mer de Glace. An outcrop of rock in the glacier, festooned with grass and flowers in summer, Le Jardin is described in detail Voyages (2: p. 28) and Murray: an oasis in this desert – an island in the ice – a rock which is covered with a beautiful herbage, and enamelled, in August, with flowers – as this is the Jardin of this palace of nature, and nothing can exceed the beauty of such a spot, amidst the overwhelming sublimity of the surrounding objects (p. 412).Still comparatively difficult of access in SG’s day – Raffles’ guide ‘assured us that the toil would be in vain, as the season was not sufficiently advanced’ (Raffles, p. 167) – by the middle of the 1830s guides led frequent excursions.
enthusiastically…deities: On SG’s relation with ‘romance’, see introduction and cp. Note 152.

the mighty thunderer: ‘Jupiter, the most powerful of all the gods of the ancients […] He is generally represented as sitting upon a golden or ivory throne, holding, in one hand, thunderbolts just ready to be hurled, and, in the other, a sceptre of cypress’ (Lemprière).
Vulcan: ‘a god of the ancients who presided over fire, and was the patron of all artists who worked iron and metals […] lame of one foot’ (Lemprière); the blacksmith of the Classical pantheon.
the…creation: Cp. Note 98.
precipitated: ‘thrown’ or ‘driven’ (OED I.1), but cf. also OED III.5: ‘To deposit, or cause to be deposited, in a solid form from solution in a liquid, by chemical action’.

Pluto: ‘Pluto, a son of Saturn and Ops, inherited his father’s kingdom with his brothers Jupiter and Neptune. He received as his lot the kingdom of hell, and whatever lies under the earth, and as such he became the god of the infernal regions, of death and funerals’ (Lemprière).

Cerberus: ‘Cerberus, a dog of Pluto, the fruit of Echidna’s union with Typhon. He had fifty heads according to Hesiod, and three according to other mythologies. He was stationed at the entrance into hell, as a watchful keeper, to prevent the living from entering the infernal regions, and the dead from escaping from their confinement’ (Lemprière).
Old Charon: ‘A god of hell, son of Erebus and Nor, who conducted the souls of the dead in a boat over the river Styx and Acheron to the infernal regions, for an obolus [coin]’ (Lemprière).

flaming Tartarus: ‘one of the regions of hell, where, according to the ancients, the most impious and guilty among mankind were punished. It was surrounded with a brazen wall, and its entrance was continually hidden from the sight by a cloud of darkness, which is represented as three times more gloomy than the obscurest night’ (Lemprière).
the regions…snow: In the Inferno of Dante Alighieri (1265-1321), the lowest region of hell is a lake of ice, with Satan frozen at its centre.

scourges…race: Candidates for this distinction who are mentioned in Description presumably include Napoleon Bonaparte (see Notes 5, 12), Hannibal of Carthage (see Note 14), and Alexander the Great (Note 130). It is tempting to speculate about which other, contemporary military commanders SG might have had in mind. Cp. Percy Shelley, An Address to the People on the Death of the Princess Charlotte (1817): ‘Kings and their ministers have in every age been distinguished from other men by a thirst for expenditure and bloodshed’ (paragraph VIII). See SG’s Note 2 and Note 10 to SG’s Preface.
spirits…sovereigns: It is difficult not to detect here an allusion to Radical critique of the notoriously profligate George IV (1762-1830) of the United Kingdom.

Court parasites: Another expression which seems to cry out to be associated with Radical critique of unpopular members of the Liverpool administration in the UK, including Robert Stewart, Viscount Castlereagh (1769-1822), secretary of state (1812-1822), and John Scott, Earl of Eldon (1751-1838), Lord Chancellor (1807-27). Cp. the general tenor of this passage with Percy Shelley, ‘England in 1819’ (1819) and ‘The Mask of Anarchy (1819), which of course SG could not (presumably) have known.
nature…years: Quoting Addison, Cato, a Tragedy (1731), V i 26-7: ‘The stars shall fade away, the sun himself / Grow dim with age, and nature sink in years’.

O Thou!...were: Adapting Satan’s speech from Milton, Paradise Lost, iv, 32-8. Milton has the first person singular in lines 35 and 37, and lines 38-9 read ‘That bring to my remembrance from what state / I fell’.
The material in speech marks is not, insofar as I have been able to determine, quoted from another source.
the path: The majority of the final section of Description is a condensed translation of Saussure’s account of his ascent of Mont Blanc in Voyages (4: pp. 137-226); see introduction.
This…continent: Cp. Troye: ‘MONT BLANC is the most elevated spot in Europe’ (p. 1).

15,662 feet: = 2450 toises, the (more or less accurate) figure given by Saussure, using French units of measurement, in Voyages (4: p. 192), based on barometric readings at the summit, and with ‘la plus grande confiance’ [‘with the greatest confidence’ (my translation)]. Saussure’s figure was subsequently well-circulated (e.g. Coxe, p. 200), so it is curious that Troye gives a very inaccurate 14556 English feet.

the WHITE VALLEY: (45º 53’ N, 6º 55’ E) La Vallée Blanche, a glacial valley at the centre of the Mont Blanc massif. Described in detail by Saussure in Voyages (2: pp. 237-44). See also Voyages 4: p. 138.

The attempts…mountain: Saussure describes in detail attempts up until 1785 in Voyages 2: pp. 468-87 and between 1785 and his own ascent in Voyages 4: pp. 137-40. See also Coxe, pp. 185-7. It was common for guidebooks to give brief histories of attempts on the summit.
PEAKE DU GOUTE: (45º 51’ 02” N, 6º 49’ 52” E) Aiguille du Goûter (3863m). See Voyages 4: p. 138.
DOME DU GOUTE: (45º 50’ 34” N, 6º 50’ 36” E) Dome du Goûter (4304m). See Voyages 4: pp. 138-9.
An interesting choice of phrase, given SG’s condemnation of the importance placed on chance by atheistic natural philosophy in his Preface to Description.

BALMAT: Jacques Balmat (1762-1834), a hunter and crystal collector from Chamonix. On 8 August 1786, he and Michael-Gabriel Paccard completed the first successful ascent of Mont Blanc. The circumstances under which Balmat previously discovered a practicable route to summit are described in Voyages (4: pp. 139-40). Balmat served as guide during Horace-Bénédict de Saussure’s successful ascent of Mont Blanc the following year. A statue in central Chamonix commemorates their relationship. See also Note 38 and introduction.
these…regions: Cp. Voyages (4: p. 139): ‘ces vastes & inconnues solitudes’.

Horace-Bénédict de Saussure (1740-99), Swiss natural philosopher who documented his extensive researches in the Alps in Voyages and Abregée; he completed an ascent of Mont Blanc on 3 August 1787. See also Note 38 and introduction.

the Macedonian…ravages: Alexander II of Macedon (356-23 BC), pupil of Aristotle, whose military conquests won him an empire from Greece to India. In his Anabasis Alexandri [The Anabasis of Alexander], the Classical Greek historian Arrian of Nicomedia (92-175) noted Alexander’s weakness for alcohol. The epithets ‘great’ and ‘godlike’ all have provenance in Classical literature and were still current in SG’s time.
MONTANVERT: Montenvers. See Note 91.
many…chosen: Quoting Matthew 22: 14 ‘For many are called, but few are chosen’.

the rarification…rapidity: Cp. Voyages (4: p. 207):Mais de tous nos organs, celui qui est le plus affecté par la rareté de l’air, c’est celui de la respiration […] Si donc l’air qu’ils respirent est le double plus rare, il faudra que leurs inspirations soient le double plus fréquentes […] C’est cette accéleration forcée de la respiration qui est la cause de la fatigue & des angoisses que l’on éprouve à ces grandes hauteurs. Car en même tems que la respiration accélere, la circulation s’accélere aussi. [Of all our organs, that which is most affected by the rarity of the air is that of respiration […] If then the air which they breathe is twice as rarified, their respiration has to be twice as frequent […] It is this acceleration forced by the respiration which is the cause of the fatigue and suffering one experiences at these great elevations. Because as the breathing accelerates, the circulation [‘pulsation’] accelerates also. (my translation)]For heart rate at the summit of Mont Blanc, see also Abregée, p. 28.
the vast abyss: Cp. Voyages 4: p. 167.
the line of march: That is, the general direction of travel rather than a specific path.
Hamlet of DU MONT: (45° 53’ 53” N, 6° 50’ 33” E) Le Mont; see Voyages 4: p. 150.
covered…funnels: Described in Voyages 4: p. 150, which gives the same explanation for why the caverns (‘creux’) are ‘en forme d’entonnoirs’ [‘in the form of funnels’ (my translation)].

coup d’Oeil: View, taken in at a glance. Cp. Voyages 4: p. 151, which describes the ascent at this point as ‘très sauvage’. Cp. Raffles on Chamonix: ‘the coup d’oeil was most grand and imposing’ (p. 186).
la Moraine: ‘Moraine’ = debris on the lateral edges of a glacier. At this point in Voyages (4: pp. 151-2), Saussure is describing the moraine of the Glacier du Tacconaz (see Note 83).

Le Mauvais Pas: A difficult and dangerous couloir, about thirty minutes climb above the Glacier du Tacconaz, described in Voyages 4: p. 152. For the general application of the term (= ‘a difficult passage’), cp. Percy Shelley’s account of his ascent to the Mer de Glace in SWT, p. 164: The cabin of Montanvert is three leagues from Chamouni, half of which distance is performed on mules, not so sure footed, but that on the first day the one which I rode fell in what the guides call a mauvais pas, so that I narrowly escaped being precipitated down the mountain.
a Grotto: Described in Voyages 4: pp. 152-3.
The view…magnificent: Described in Voyages 4: p. 153.

See…frame: Quoting Richard Blackmore (1654-1729), Creation; A Philosophical Poem, in Seven Books (1712), I, ll. 34-47, with slight changes. Blackmore’s text has ‘Creating power’ not ‘Creative might’ (l. 36); ‘his care’ not ‘his power’ (l. 37); l. 43 reads ‘Th’ imprison’d sea, that restless ebbs and flows’; and l. 46 reads ‘And the wide regions of the land, proclaim’. These changes made by SG, along with his greater use of capitalisation, not only anchor the scene in an Alpine landscape but increase the devotional tone of the extract.

the Bird’s Beak: Cp. Voyages 4: p. 153: ‘L’un de ces blocs, dont un angle saillant se projette en sort en avant au-dessus du précipice se nomme à cause de cela le bec à oiseau’ [‘One of these blocks, of which a projecting angle points outwards above the precipice, is called the bird’s beak’ (my translation; original emphasis)]. Saussure does not mention the accident SG describes and I have found no record of it.
journey: Which Saussure puts at six-and-a-half hours from Chamonix (Voyages 4: p. 155).
Here…ice: Cp. Voyages (4: p. 155): ‘C’est-là que l’on quitte la terre ferme & qu l’on s’embarque sur les glaces & sur les neiges jusques à la fin du voyage’.

Where…snows: Either misquoting from memory or intentionally re-assembling various lines from James Thomson, The Seasons, ‘Winter’:
Where undissolving, from the first of time.
Snows swell on snows amazing to the sky
And icy mountains high on mountains pil’d (ll. 904)
’Tis done! dread Winter spreads his latest glooms.
And reigns tremendous o’er the conquered year (ll. 1024-5)
And through his airy hall the loud misrule
Of driving tempest is for ever heard:
Here the grim tyrant meditates his wrath;
Here arms his winds with all-subduing frost ;
Moulds his fierce hail, and treasures up his snows (ll. 896-901)
slight…snow: See Voyages (4: p. 157) on the dangers of snow-covered crevasses.
a guide…COUTET: Joseph Marie Coutet (dates unknown). The episode is described in Voyages 4: p. 157; SG’s phrasing exaggerates the danger in comparison to Saussure’s account.

another guide: This episode is not in Saussure’s detailed account in Voyages, on which SG draws throughout this section of Description, but cp. the different account of Coutet’s accident given in Abregée (pp. 8-9), and Voyages 4: p. 143.
I deal…romance: A prime example of SG’s use of apophasis in Description. For his attitude to ‘romance’, see introduction and cp. Note 104.

melancholy circumstance: I have found no source for this ‘melancholy circumstance’, but whilst the details seem exaggerated – and purposively intended to critique the careless frivolity of the nobility – SG does not tend altogether to fabricate such material in Description and he may well be embellishing some actual accident.

The heat…tent: Saussure gives just a brief account of the discomforts of this second night in his extended account of the ascent (Voyages 4: p. 165). In Abregée, however, he describes in more detail the spectacular view which greeted him when he left the tent for a few moments to get some air: Mes guides toujours préoccupés de la crainte du froid, fermèrent si exactement tous les joints de la tente, que je souffris beaucoup de la chaleur & de l’air corrompu par notre respiration. Je fus obligé de sortir dans la nuit pour respirer. La lune brilloit du plus grand éclat au milieu d’un ciel d’un noir d’ébêne; Jupiter sortoit tout rayonnant aussi de lumière, de derrière la plus haute cime à l'est du Mont Blanc, & la lumière réverbérée par tout ce bassin de neiges étoit sì éblouissante , qu’on ne pouvoit distinguer que les étoiles de la première & de la seconde grandeur (pp. 12-13; and in Voyages 4: pp. 145-5). [My guides, always preoccupied with the fear of the cold, closed so closely all the joints of the tent, that I suffered greatly from the heat and the air corrupted by our breathing. I was obliged to go out into the night to breathe. The moon shone with the greatest brilliance in the midst of a sky of an ebony black; Jupiter was also radiant with light, from behind the highest summit to the east of Mont Blanc, and the light reverberated by this whole pool of snow was so dazzling that one could only distinguish the stars of the first and the second magnitudes (my translation)]One of the most celebrated passages of Abregée, this description was often given in precis form in contemporary guidebooks (e.g. Coxe, p. 191). The extended description of the sky and landscape, the apostrophe to the ‘beauteous’ works of nature, and the attacks on atheists which comprise the remainder of this and the next two paragraphs of Description are SG’s own.
outlustering: ‘Outshining’; the spelling is rare.
vying with the bow of Iris: ‘competing with the rainbow’; in Greek myth, Iris, the goddess of the rainbow, was the messenger of the gods.
a tale…serpent: Cp. Macbeth V v 28-8: ‘[Life] is a tale / Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury / Signifying nothing’; and I v 66-7: ‘look like th ’innocent flower, / But be the serpent under ’t’.

horror…must be: Adapting Milton’s account of Satan in Paradise Lost iv 18-26:
horror and doubt distract
His troubled thoughts, and from the bottom stir
The hell within him, for within him hell
He brings, and round about him, nor from hell
One step no more than from himself can fly
By change of place: now conscience wakes despair
That slumbered, wakes the bitter memory
Of what he was, what is, and what must be
Worse; of worse deeds worse sufferings must ensue.

the Divinity…to man: Adapting Joseph Addison, Cato, a Tragedy (1731), V i 4-8:
why shrinks the soul
Back on herself, and startles at destruction?
’Tis the divinity that stirs within us;
’Tis heaven itself, that points out an hereafter,
And intimates eternity to man.
The first beams: SG’s close adherence to Saussure’s account in Voyages resumes here, picking up at Voyages 4: p. 166.
two more hours: The timeframe given by Saussure (Voyages 4: p. 168).

impossible…sufficiently: As described by Saussure in his detailed account of the ascent (Voyages 4: pp. 175-6), where he records that he almost fainted on first gaining the summit and was initially alarmed that he would not be able to make any observations or experiments at all. No mention of these difficulties is made in Abregée. The overwhelming impact of the Alpine sublime had of course also been a familiar trope of writing about Chamonix-Mont Blanc since Windham and Pococke’s seminal account of being ‘extremely at a loss’ for how to describe the Mer de Glace (Windham, p. 9). Cp. similar experiences in Relation: such is the engrossing nature of these objects, that they seem to efface every other idea. We are no longer our own masters; and it is next to an impossibility to stop the impulse of our inclinations (p. 114).Cp. also SWT, pp. 151-2: ‘The immensity of these aerial summits excited, when they suddenly burst upon the sight, a sentiment of extatic wonder, not unallied to madness’.
impossible…remain: Saussure and his party remained approximately four-and-a-half hours, making observations and performing experiments (Voyages 4: p. 213; Abregée, p. 17).
so narrow…abreast: As confirmed by Saussure, in exactly these terms (Voyages 4: p. 176).
West side: SG’s geography is out here; it is (as Saussure notes) the steep, south face which leads down to the Vallée Blanche (Voyages 4: p. 176).
To the…air: The experimental observations given in this paragraph are all provided by Saussure in his extended account of his ascent of Mont Blanc in Voyages, and some of them also in Abregée.
the chafing dish: ‘A heating dish’ (from the French chauffage). Saussure describes these difficulties in Voyages 4: p. 202.
half…water: Confirmed experimentally by Saussure (Voyages 4: p. 202).
a tube: That is, a telescope. See Voyages 4: pp. 198-9 for Saussure’s remarks on the sky conditions at the summit of Mont Blanc.
a Chinese cracker: A small firecracker. The exact comparison made by Saussure (Voyages 4: pp. 206-7).

so piercing…inkhorns: Details provided by Saussure (Voyages 4: p. 168), but cp. a more or less exact precedent for SG’s phrasing in the account given by Coxe of the first ascent of Mont Blanc by Balmat and Paccard: ‘The cold was so intense, that their provision was frozen in their pockets, the ink congealed in their inkhorns’ (p. 186). ‘inkhorns’ = portable containers for writing ink.

O Thou…ALL!: Here SG adapts and combines extracts from James Thomson’s ‘Winter’ and ‘Summer’. The first 5 lines are taken from ‘Winter’ (ll. 106-10) but SG gives them a religious inflexion by replacing Thomson’s secular address to ‘Nature! great parent!’ with ‘O Thou! great parent’. Lines 6-12 of SG’s text are taken from Thomson’s ‘Summer’ (ll. 185-91), with minor changes in punctuation and, more significantly, the introduction of capitalisation in ll. 39 and 43 to heighten the devotional element of the text.

Models: See introduction. A handbill advertising an exhibition of Troye’s models in 1819, at 20 Frith Street, Soho, now in the collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum, London, is available here: http://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O1248040/handbill-c-handy/ Thomas Raffles was shown ‘A beautiful model of the Alps of Savoy, executed in relief’ by his guide at Chamonix, ‘a Monsieur Crotet’, who had already served as guide to the Princess of Wales (Raffles, p. 137). It is tempting to assume, though of course impossible to prove, that this model was made by Troye. It is also tempting to assume that Raffles’ well-connected guide ‘Crotet’ was in fact Joseph Marie Coutet, who had accompanied Saussure on his first ascent of Mont Blanc (see Notes 38 and 150).

Mont Cenis: (45º 15’ 37” N, 06º 54’ 03” E). A massif (3612m) on the border between France and Italy. Coxe concludes his account of the Aosta valley, in northwest Italy, that ‘Those who do not wish to pursue the tour of Italy, may return from Turin to Lyons or Geneva, over Mont Cenis, in the diligence, which traverses the magnificent new road made over that fine Alp by Napoleon Bonaparte [in 1801-3]’ (pp. 172-3).

St. Gothard: (46º 38’ 28” N, 8º 25’ 06” E). ‘Mont St. Gothard is one of the wildest and most interesting mountain-passes in Switzerland, and few persons of taste return from this country without having visited it’ (Coxe, p. 163). The route across the pass involved the famous ‘Devil’s Bridge’ across the waterfall of Reuss: ‘a sublime scene of horror’ (Coxe, p. 164).
J. B. TROYE: Jean-Baptiste Troye (dates unknown), Swiss painter and sculptor; father of the American painter Edward Troye (1808-74). For his connection with SG, see introduction.
A LONG RESIDENCE IN SWISSERLAND: See introduction.

Her late Royal Highness…Coburg: Princess Charlotte of Wales (1796-1817), the only child of the Prince Regent, later George IV (1762-1830), who died on 5 November 1817, aged 21, after giving birth to a stillborn son. Charlotte was thought favourable to the cause of parliamentary reform and her death (which provoked a massive outpouring of public grief) came as a blow to supporters of that cause. In his Address to the People on the Death of the Princess Charlotte (1817), Percy Bysshe Shelley took the occasion to lament the death of English liberty. See Note 114 and Note 11 to SG’s Preface to Description.
His Royal Highness…Gloucester: Prince William Frederick (1776-1834), Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh, was the nephew and son-in-law of George III (1738-1820) of the United Kingdom.
the principal Engineer: Ignaz Venetz (1788-1859), who served as engineer for the Swiss Cantons of Valais and Vaud. See Pictet pp. 87n., 89.
seeking…devour: Adapting 1 Peter 5:8: ‘Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour’.

the mild…Christianity: Whilst references to Christianity as a mild religion are hardly recondite in the period, SG might echo here a difficult and much-discussed passage of Shelley’s ‘Mont Blanc’: ‘The wilderness has a mysterious tongue/ Which teaches awful doubt, or faith so mild,/ So solemn, so serene, that man may be/ But for such faith with nature reconciled’ (ll. 76-9).

p.note: In…Switzerland: SG’s reflection on ‘the clerical character’ and its influence on social mores in this and the following two paragraphs seems to reflect the unflattering remarks about ‘the state of religion’ in Geneva and Paris made in Letters XV and XIV of Raffles (p. 133), and the minor public controversy to which those remarks gave rise (and hence when SG refers to ‘this country’, he means France, and not England). ‘Few of the doctrines, and little of the spirit, which once rendered it the glory of the Protestant world’, Raffles says of Geneva, ‘now remain’, and he also notes, in the Alps, what he describes as ‘monuments of superstition’, including the selling of indulgences (Raffles, pp. 133, 193-4n.). ‘When I contemplate the present state of France’, Raffles laments:I see one part of the population the victims of the grossest superstition, and under the deadly influence of a mercenary and an artful priesthood […] I behold another part, bowing at the shrine of infidelity, and devoted only to the gratification of their sensual appetites and basest passions […] I see the few who profess a purer system, and who ought to shew a better way, sunk in the arms of a spiritual apathy, as dead to the things of God – as unconcerned about the Redeemer’s kingdom – as indifferent to their own eternal interests – as gay, as volatile, as much the lovers of pleasure, as the rest (pp. 96-7).Geneva, of course, had been part of the Swiss Confederation since 1814. The fact that both Raffles and SG still connect it with France is explained by their desire to see the atheistic principles of the French Revolution as the primary cause of the decline of public religion. Raffles singles out Voltaire (1694-1778), whose house in Paris he refused to visit on point of principle, as ‘the bitterest and most malignant enemy of the Redeemer, that ever, perhaps, appeared in a human form!’ (p. 139). As the Advertisement to the third edition of Raffles observes, Helen Maria Williams (1759-1827) attacked publically, in her Letters on Events which have passed in France since the Restoration in 1815 (London, 1819), what she saw as Raffles’ unfair criticism of French Protestants – an attack rebutted in the appraisal of Williams’ Letters given by the Eclectic Review for September 1819.

div.p: reverting to events: ‘Revert’ = ‘to return to, or recall’ (see OED 6).
good deeds…brass: Cp. Shakespeare, Henry VIII IV ii 45-6: ‘Men’s evil manners live in brass; their virtues/ We write in water’.

Chance…sound: The repudiation of ‘chance’ as a potential author of the universe was one of the key tenets of the so-called teleological argument, or argument from design, in support of the existence of a creator-God. Influential proponents of this argument included William Derham (1657-1735) and William Paley (1743-1805), whose Natural Theology; or, Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of The Deity, Collected from the Appearances of Nature (1802) became, for the nineteenth century, the seminal statement of the position. See, for example, Paley, Natural Theology (14th edition; 1813), pp. 62-3:I desire no greater certainty in reasoning, than that by which chance is excluded from the present disposition of the natural world. Universal experience is against it. What does chance ever do for us? In the human body, for instance, chance, i.e. the operation of causes without design, may produce a wen, a wart, a mole, a pimple, but never an eye.
visionary: ‘Imaginary’.
the universal…fair: Quoting Milton, Paradise Lost V 153-5: ‘These are thy glorious works, parent of good,/ Almighty, thine this universal frame,/ Thus wondrous fair’.
we live…being: Cp. Acts 17:28: ‘For in him we live, and move, and have our being; as certain also of your own poets have said, For we are also his offspring.’
the great globe…inhabits: Cp. Shakespeare, The Tempest IV i 153-4: ‘the great Globe it self,/ Yea, all which it inherits, shall dissolve’.

with life…the grave: Perhaps an echo of Alexander Pope, An Essay on Man (1734) IV 93-8:
Oh blind to truth, and God’s whole scheme below,
Who fancy bliss to vice, to virtue woe!
Who sees and follows that great scheme the best,
Best knows the blessing, and will most be blest.
But fools the good alone unhappy call,
For ills or accidents that chance to all. It is tempting also to detect a distant echo of Percy Shelley’s account of the execution of the leaders of the so-called ‘Pentridge Rising’ in his Address to the People on the Death of the Princess Charlotte (1817) vi: ‘Brandreth was calm, and evidently believed that the consequences of our errors were limited by that tremendous barrier [death]. Ludlam and Turner were full of fears’. Shelley’s Address had extremely limited circulation, however – perhaps only 20 copies were printed in 1817 for private distribution – and so for SG to have known it, he would almost certainly have to have had a close connection with the Shelley circle. SG refers to ‘Her late Royal Highness the Princess Charlotte of Saxe Coburg’ in a footnote to the main text of Description (p. 33).
the hour…dissolution: In both this Preface and the main text of Description, SG frequently invokes death-bed scenes, already a staple of the sentimental novel.
waking…birth of man: Adapting Thomson, The Seasons, ‘Winter’, ll. 377-8: ‘’Tis come, the Glorious Morn! the second Birth/ Of Heaven, and Earth!’ (original emphasis).

where…all: Adapting Thomson’s account of the heavenly reward for earthly suffering in The Seasons, ‘Winter’, ll. 1068-9: ‘The storms of Wintry Time will quickly pass, / And one unbounded Spring encircle all!’.
the anatomy…frame: In Chapter VIII of Natural Theology, Paley argues that ‘mechanical arrangement in the human frame’ is ‘evidently artificial’ (p. 92), that is, is evidence of divine design.
